question.text: The lanthanide contraction is responsible for the fact that

options.text: <math><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext></math> and <math><mtext>Y</mtext></math> have about the same radii
<math><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>r</mtext></math> and <math><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>f</mtext></math> have almost the same radii
<math><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>r</mtext></math>  and  <math><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>n</mtext></math>  have the same oxidation state

solution.text: There is a regular decrease in the atomtextc and ionic radii of lanthanide from <math><mtext>L</mtext><mtext>a</mtext></math> to <math><mtext>L</mtext><mtext>u</mtext></math> . This decrease in radii is a unique feature and is known as lanthanide contraction. It is due to greater effect of the increased nuclear charge than that of the screening effect. As a result of lanthanide contraction the normal increase in size from <math><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>c</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>Y</mtext><mo>→</mo><mtext>L</mtext><mtext>a</mtext></math> disappears after the lanthanide series and the pair of elements like <math><mtext>Z</mtext><mtext>r</mtext></math> and <math><mtext>H</mtext><mtext>f</mtext></math> have almost the same radii.
